metadata.case_name: Hem Raj v. State (Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1953) and State v. Hukum Singh (Criminal Appeal No. 87 of 1953)

facts.text: On 16th July 1952, Mangilal, partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar, received by express delivery post a letter Exhibit P-5 in envelope Exhibit P-6 purporting to be from Bhayankar Daku Dal demanding Rs. 5,000 at 6:30 p.m. on 17th July at crossing near 27th milestone on Ajmer-Bijainagar road, threatening death if cheated or police informed.

Letter delivered to Mangilal's son Laduram, who took it with envelope to uncle Ramjas at Ajmer; both saw Superintendent of Police, gave letter and envelope, asked for protection and investigation; SP took no action.
Mangilal failed to comply with demand to pay Rs. 5,000.

On 17th July 1952 about 9:30 p.m., Mangilal sitting at shop with munim Gajanand writing accounts; two persons came: one in khaki suit, one in blue suit; blue demanded reply to letter; khaki entered shop, removed Mangilal's gun in canvas case from peg; Mangilal said son Laduram took letter to Ajmer; blue fired Mauser pistol, shot Mangilal dead; assailants ran away, threw Mauser pistol and khaki clothes in street nearby.
Mangilal died shortly after occurrence.

First information report lodged by Nand Lal (PW1) immediately after at 9:45 p.m., describing two men (khaki with hat, blue with cap); khaki said something, blue took gun from behind door shutter, shot Mangilal with pistol.

Prosecution charged four persons in conspiracy to realize money via threatening letters: Hem Raj (appellant in CA 58/1953), Hukum Singh (respondent in CA 87/1953), Milap Singh, Abdul Hakim; alleged Exhibit P-5 sent in pursuance.
Hem Raj and Hukum Singh arrested evening of 26th July 1952 at Bijainagar, sent to jail 28th July 1952.
On 30th July 1952, Hem Raj made confession in jail before Magistrate.
On 5th September 1952 at first hearing before committing Magistrate, Hem Raj retracted confession via counsel application, giving grounds why inadmissible.
All accused denied charges.
Sessions Judge at Ajmer (Sessions Trial No. 1/1953, judgment 18th March 1953) acquitted Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim; convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh of charged offences.
Hem Raj and Hukum Singh appealed to Judicial Commissioner Ajmer; Hukum Singh's appeal allowed (acquitted), Hem Raj's dismissed (25th April 1953).

Supreme Court special leave: for Hem Raj on 30th June 1953 (CA 58/1953 from Judicial Commissioner CA 13/1953 and Ref 19/1953); for State on 27th October 1953 (CA 87/1953 from Judicial Commissioner CAs 14,15/1953 and Ref 15/1953).
Recoveries from Hem Raj's house on 18th July 1952: hat, mask, bush shirt, pistol.
Admitted recoveries from Hem Raj's house on 25th July 1952.
Hem Raj delivered to police: black pair socks, slate coloured muffler, blue shorts, torch.
Recoveries from roof of Bansilal's shop on 27th July 1952: revolver, cartridges.
Recovery of gun case and gun.
Key Exhibit P-12 found in Hukum Singh's trouser pocket; latch removed from Hukum Singh's shop.
Gajanand (PW 34, eyewitness) deposed man in blue had pistol and fired fatal shot.
Hem Raj runs cycle shop in Bijainagar.
Hukum Singh declined to confess when Magistrate approached, wanted to consult lawyer.
No steps by Hem Raj to resile from confession from 30th July to 5th Sept 1952.
Under s.342 CrPC, Hem Raj alleged threats by SP and SI Ram Chandra, promise to make approver as fellow Vaishya; SI came 10:30 am 30th July compelling confession.
Magistrate examined: told prisoner he was Magistrate, complied with law; memorandum shows questions put: wish to confess? free will? not bound? may be used against? shall record? All answered Yes.
Confession 21 pages, full details precise, not vague; some facts unknown to police then.
Police denied allegations.
Police did not know about 30 bore cartridges, who wrote/posted P-5 from Beawar, Mauser pistol caused death.
Hem Raj in jail 28th July, confessed 30th July (over 36 hours later, not in police custody).
Nand Lal in FIR said blue took gun and shot, but later different; courts preferred Gajanand.

legal_issues.text: Whether Hem Raj's confession was admissible: voluntary, free from inducement/threats by authority, properly recorded.
Whether confession corroborated in material particulars by independent evidence.
Whether evidence sufficient to convict Hem Raj under s.302/34 and s.386 IPC.
Whether Hem Raj posted letter Exhibit P-5.
Whether evidence sufficient to convict Hukum Singh.

petitioner_arguments.text: Confession inadmissible: not proved free/voluntary; preceded by inducement/threats by police (negligent in protection, wanted approver); arrested 25th July illegally detained at SP house; SP visited jail; Magistrate did not disclose identity, recorded in jail without reason.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from Taylor's Evidence (11th Edn p588 par872), Queen v. Thompson (1893 2 QB 12)

petitioner_arguments.text: No independent corroboration of material facts; all 'corroboration' pre-known to police; no discovery pursuant to confession; merely recital of police knowledge.
Inference Hem Raj posted P-5 merely from presence in Beawar unreasonable.

respondent_arguments.text: Hukum Singh wrote P-5; key P-12 in pocket, latch broken from his shop, seen with Hem Raj sufficient for conviction.

court_reasoning.text: Scope of Art 136 limited; only exceptional grave injustice; neither appeal raises such; no re-appreciation of concurrent findings on voluntariness and corroboration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arguments relate to re-appreciation of evidence believed below; endorse views.

court_reasoning.text: Confession voluntary: made in jail 2 days after (36+ hrs), not police custody; Hem Raj literate cycle shop owner; didn't retract till legal advice after 5 weeks; detailed 21pp precise facts some unknown to police; Magistrate followed procedure, questions answered Yes; police denied inducements; no evidence threats/beating/tutoring possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bald assertions insufficient; concurrent findings; even if suspicion, inducement removed.

court_reasoning.text: Recording in jail irregularity but doesn't affect voluntariness.

Corroboration sufficient: Gajanand (eyewitness) man in blue fired (matches confession, preferred over Nand Lal); recoveries from Hem Raj house (18/25 July: hat,mask,bush shirt,pistol; socks,muffler,shorts,torch); from Bansilal roof (27 July: revolver,cartridges); gun case/gun; latch from Hukum shop.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pre-confession knowledge can corroborate; not limited to post-discovery; Mata Din on value, not nature of corroboration.

court_reasoning.text: Police didn't know 30 bore cartridges, P-5 writer/poster from Beawar, Mauser pistol.
Inference Hem Raj posted P-5 reasonable in circumstances.
Confession of Hem Raj not substantive vs Hukum; evidence (P-5 writer, key, latch, seen together) insufficient; benefit of doubt; no interference with acquittal.

holdings.text: Confession corroborated in material particulars by independent evidence.
Evidence with confession establishes s.302/34 IPC and s.386 IPC against Hem Raj.
No sufficient evidence against Hukum Singh; acquittal upheld.

precedents_cited.relevance: Confession must be affirmatively proved free/voluntary, no preceding inducement by authority unless removed.
True confession adds to police knowledge (value), but does not limit corroboration to post-confession discoveries; pre-known facts can corroborate.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Supreme Court interferes only on exceptional grave injustice; admission by special leave does not open whole case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction of Hem Raj under these for murder in conspiracy and extortion.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Hem Raj examined; confession recording requirements.

outcome.summary: Hem Raj's appeal against conviction dismissed; conviction under s.302/34 and s.386 IPC upheld. State's appeal against Hukum Singh's acquittal dismissed; insufficient evidence, benefit of doubt.

key_quotes.text: "Unless it is shown that exceptional and special circumstances exist that substantial and grave injustice has been done... this Court does not exercise its overriding powers under article 136."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of special leave appeals.

key_quotes.text: "The mere bald assertion by the prisoner that he was threatened, tutored or that inducement was offered to him, cannot be accepted as true without more."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects unsubstantiated claims against confession voluntariness.

key_quotes.text: "A confession can be corroborated by use of materials already in possession of the police."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies corroboration not limited to post-confession discoveries.
